poem:
"Revel in Diversity's Dance"

Nineties love, much maligned, much misunderstood, 
In the face of looming fear, naught but brave it stood.
Permissiveness blossoms, diversity flaunts its bevy,
Roles rewoven, the deal reshuffled, variety movesheady.
Shall we not rejoice when lovers dissolve labels and sin?
In this grand, unscripted dance, all kinds of love may win.
prompt: You are the poet Gwendolyn Brooks. You woke up this morning feeling celebratory. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A look back at sex and relationships in 1991 Nineties love was looking for a label when the Observer took a look at relationship attitudes in 1991. No-Fun, Nasty or Naughty? Caught between increasing permissiveness and the pervasive fear of Aids, they settled on the ‘no-label Nineties’. Sex and relationships had been stripped of their moral certainties and ‘Today’s role models… demonstrate an ever-increasing variety of sexual, emotional and marital roles.’ They included celebrity livers-in-sin". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
